--------------DD3994FBBEA88F40C09958E5
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

For the sake of discussing software engineering, I'd like to point out that it
is often less productive to use a debugger. Consider that using
org.log4j.Category as a class var in your program, then: (assuming you have a
Debug class with a booleans SHALLOW, MEDIUM, DEEP )

if( Debug.SHALLOW )
    Log_.debug( "got to just after xxx, someVar="+someVar )

Here is a sample out put using Log_.info(..) in a debug run (actually a jUnit
test case.)

0 [main] INFO com.popetools.util.Debug  - util.debug.static.OpenAppender(..):
log opened successfully.
.370 [main] INFO com.popetools.unittest.PersistenceManagerExceptionTest  -
testCurrTransWhileClosed passed.

The first field indicates the millis that elapsed since the start of
execution, and the 3rd field indicates the class emitting the output, and the
rest of the line is the emitted information.

After you've debugged the code, you replace the SHALLOW with MEDIUM, or DEEP
considering on the level of detail output it produces.

This way, the poor sod who makes a change to your code later, and needs to
debug it, already has the important debug state-check points indicated.
He/she simply has to replace the MEDIUM with SHALLOW, turn on Debug.SHALLOW,
and presto, they can debug your code with minimal effort.

In the long haul, such schemes save time and effort.  Using a debugger should
be the last thing you do to debug a module.  It takes a lot of time.

Regards,
Matthew

Carolyn MacLeod/OTT/OTI wrote:

> Try Eclipse.
> http://www.eclipse.org/
>
> Carolyn
>
> Russ Baker <rbaker@...>

>
> Hello,
>
> I have been stuck using jBuilder to debug my code.  Well, after fighting
> with the IDE for months now, I have come to the conclusion that, for lack
> of
> better verbiage, jBuilder's (4.0) debugger is flaky.  The debugger
> constantly goes into code that it shouldn't, and actually forces me to go
> back to using the old System.out method of debugging, how wasteful!
>
> Does anyone know of a decent debugger?  I am currently using the jdk1.3.1.
>
> Thanks in advance,
>
> Russ Baker
